title: Question 1
content:
Which equation represents condensation?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}\textrm{(l)} \longrightarrow \ce{Br2}\textrm{(g)}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{H2O}\textrm{(g)} \longrightarrow \ce{H2O}\textrm{(l)}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{CO2}\textrm{(s)} \longrightarrow \ce{CO2}\textrm{(g)}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NaOH}\textrm{(aq)} + \ce{HCl}\textrm{(aq)} \longrightarrow \ce{NaCl}\textrm{(aq)} + \ce{H2O}\textrm{(l)}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Condensation occurs when a gas changes into a liquid.
Students must distinguish changes in states of matter from chemical reactions (such as the neutralization reaction between sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid).
This question is categorized as easy as students are only expected to identify changes in states of matter.

title: Question 3
content:
Which of the following is an example of a mixture?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Sucrose
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Distilled water
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Seawater
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Sodium chloride
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Seawater is a mixture of water and salts. Sucrose, distilled water, and sodium chloride are all examples of compounds.

title: Question 4
content:
Which of the following is a characteristic of liquids?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Their particles vibrate about fixed positions.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$They can be compressed easily.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$They take up the shape of the container they are in.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$The particles move freely and quickly in all directions.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:  
Liquids have an indefinite shape (take the shape of the container) but have a definite volume (are incompressible).

title: Question 8
content:
Which of the following correctly classifies $\ce{S8}$ and water?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}$ and water are both compounds.
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}$ and water are both elements.
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}$ is a compound, and water is an element.
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}$ is an element, and water is a compound.
markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
$\ce{S8}$ is an element because it consists of only sulfur atoms bonded together. Even though it has multiple atoms, all of them are sulfur, so it's not a compound $\text{--}$ it's just a molecular form of an element (one of sulfur's allotropes), in the same way diatomic $\ce{H2}$ is an element.
Water $\ce{H2O}$ is a compound because it contains two different elements (hydrogen and oxygen) chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio of $2:1.$ This fixed ratio is what makes water a compound rather than a mixture.

title: Question 11
content: [Maximum marks: 7] Crude oil (also known as petroleum) is a homogeneous mixture of volatile liquid hydrocarbons. Before it can be used, it must be refined to separate it into simpler, more useful mixtures. - Describe a homogeneous mixture. [1] - Contrast the microscopic structure and behavior of liquids and gases using the kinetic molecular theory. [2] - State the physical property of the components of crude oil that allows them to be separated by fractional distillation. [1] - Kerosene, a fuel used in aviation, is one of the fractions obtained from crude oil. $\newline \ \newline$ - Kerosene has a boiling point of 240.00°C. Convert this temperature to Kelvin using Section 1 of the IB Chemistry Data Booklet. [1] - Explain, using the kinetic molecular theory, why kerosene vaporizes when heated. [2]
markScheme:
- uniform composition /  single$-$phase of physically$-$combined components / two or more different elements or compounds not in fixed ratios / components not chemically bonded  $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition is uniform throughout, meaning the individual components are evenly distributed and cannot be distinguished by simple observation. They appear as a single phase. Unlike compounds, the substances within a homogeneous mixture are not chemically bonded, so they retain their original chemical properties and they can combine in any ratio since they do not obey the Law of Definite Proportions.
- Any two of:
  
  
  - liquid particles are close together while gas particles are far apart $\checkmark$
  - liquid particles experience intermolecular /interatomic forces while gas particles do not $\checkmark$
  - liquids are not compressible while gases are very compressible $\checkmark$
  - liquids have a fixed volume while gases expand to fill a container $\checkmark$

  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
The particles in a liquid move freely, sliding past each other in a closely$-$packed but disordered structure.  This allows a liquid to change its shape to fit its container while maintaining a fixed volume.  Since the particles remain in close contact, liquids are not compressible.  The particles do experience attractions to one aonther (intermolecular / interatomic forces) that must be overcome to enter into the gas phase.
  The particles in a gas are in constant random motion, moving rabidly in all directions with negligible forces between them.  The particles are far apart, allowing gases to expand to fill their container and making them highly compressible.
  $\\ \newline \\$
- Different boiling points/volatility $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The components of crude oil can be separated by fractional distillation because they have different boiling points. When crude oil is heated, the hydrocarbons with the lowest boiling points evaporate first, while those with higher boiling points remain in liquid form until reaching their respective boiling temperatures.  The fractions that are removed from the sample are groups of similarly sized hydrocarbons.
- 
  - $240.00+273.15 = 513.15 \textrm{\ K}\:\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The Kelvin scale is shifted from the Celsius scale to place the 0 at absolute zero instead of the freezing point of water:
    Temperature (K) = Temperature ($^\circ$C) + 273.15
  - kinetic energy  increases, molecules move faster $\checkmark$ 
boils when molecules have enough energy to overcome intermolecular forces, and transition from liquid to gas $\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
According to the kinetic molecular theory, the temperature of a substance is directly related to the average kinetic energy of its particles. As kerosene is heated, its molecules absorb energy and move faster, increasing their kinetic energy. At the boiling point, the molecules have gained enough energy to break the intermolecular forces that hold them in the liquid state. This allows them to escape as into the gas phase, leading to vaporization.

title: Question 12
content:
Which of the following is a mixture?


- I.SolderII.AmmoniaIII.Seawater



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I, II, and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Pure substances have a definite and uniform chemical composition. Pure substances can be classified as elements if they are composed of one kind of atom or as compounds if they are composed of two or more kinds of atoms in a fixed ratio.
Ammonia ($\ce{NH3}$) is a compound and presents a $1:3$ N to H ratio. Ammonia is not a mixture.
On the other hand, mixtures have two or more substances physically combined that retain their individual properties together. The mixture composition is uniform for homogeneous mixtures and nonuniform for heterogeneous mixtures.

- Alloys are homogeneous mixtures.
- Solder is a homogeneous mixture.
- Seawater is $\ce{NaCl}$ (and other soluble compounds) dissolved in water, a homogeneous mixture.

This question is categorized as easy as students must distinguish mixtures from pure substances and apply their knowledge to some specific examples.

title: Question 14
content: Carbon undergoes combustion in the presence of oxygen, as shown below. $\ce{C(s) + O2(g) -> CO2(g)}$ Solid carbon dioxide, known as dry ice, is used in vaccine cooling and preserving blood and tissue samples. - Complete the table below by stating the term element, compound, or mixture to classify reactants and products. [1] - C(s)O$\mathbf{_2}$(g)CO$\mathbf{_2}$(g)$\hspace{1em}$ - Gaseous carbon dioxide can be converted into dry ice. State the name of this process. [1] - Evaluate the benefits of dry ice in vaccine cooling. [2] - Dry air is composed of nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and other gases. Comment on the statement below: ¨Dry air is a homogeneous mixture.¨ [2]
markScheme:
- 
  
  - 

  C(s)O$\mathbf{_2}$(g)CO$\mathbf{_2}$(g)elementelementcompound
  Award M1 if all three are correct. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
  Elements are composed of only one kind of atoms (such as C and $\ce{O2}$).
  Compounds are composed of two or more kinds of atoms in a fixed ratio (such as in the case of $\ce{CO2}$ here, with one carbon every two oxygens), and mixtures have two or more substances (either elements or compounds) physically mixed together. None of these examples given is a mixture.
- Deposition.$\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
  Deposition is the change of state from a gas into a solid.
- Any two of the following:
  $\ce{CO2(s) -> CO2(g)}$ absorbing heat; $\checkmark$
  Sublimation of carbon dioxide produces a stable/inert/non-toxic gas; $\checkmark$
  Low temperatures preserve/extend shelf-life/refrigerate; $\checkmark$
  Dry ice stays cooler and lasts longer than water ice. $\checkmark$
  OR other reasons related to these mentioned above.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
  Vaccine cooling requires keeping a vaccine at a low temperature. Vaccines can be stored by surrounding them with dry ice.
  Suppose the system is suddenly exposed to a high temperature. In that case, the heat will be used to sublime the solid carbon dioxide, avoiding the increase in the temperature of the vaccines stored.
  In addition, when carbon dioxide sublimes, absorbing heat, an inert gas is formed, avoiding the damage of the vaccines. As a result, sublimation can be effective in storing refrigerated vaccines.
- All these gases in the air are evenly distributed (appear as one layer) / air has a uniform composition;$\checkmark$
  Properties of air are constant throughout the mixture of gases. $\checkmark$

title: Question 15
content:
The heating curve of a substance is given below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12ec30ef-773c-40ce-8f65-b63c87d59de4/images/d5dea206-9bd8-4703-bb24-89ed5f0d0ebd/CH1100.png)


Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Y is the melting point.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$Along line segment MN, the solid is warming up.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Along the line segment NO, the liquid and solid state coexist.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The heating curve illustrates how energy input affects a substance: it either raises the temperature within a phase or is used to overcome intermolecular forces during a phase change.
During a flat section of the curve, the energy supplied does not increase temperature but instead drives the change of state. In segment NO, melting occurs and solid and liquid phases coexist, so Statement III is correct.
During sloped sections, the added energy increases the temperature of the substance. In segment MN, the substance is in the solid state and its temperature rises as heat is absorbed, so Statement II is correct.
Statement I is incorrect because Y corresponds to the boiling point, not the melting point.
In summary:


- MN: solid heating
- NO: melting (solid + liquid coexist)
- OP: liquid heating
- PQ: boiling (liquid + gas coexist)

This question is of medium difficulty, as students must distinguish between heating within a phase and energy changes during phase transitions.

title: Question 16
content:
Sugar must be recovered from a solution of sugar and ethanol. Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?
Hint: Ethanol is highly flammable with a boiling point of 78$\,{}^\circ$C.


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Evaporation with a Bunsen burner is appropriate.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$A hot water bath (above $78\,{}^\circ\text{C}$) can be used with an evaporating basin containing the mixture.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$Filtration is safe and appropriate for this separation.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Ethanol is highly flammable so direct heating with a Bunsen burner is unsafe. Statement I is incorrect.
The correct method is to use a hot water bath at a temperature above ethanol's boiling point. This allows ethanol to evaporate safely, leaving solid sugar in the evaporating basin. Statement II is correct.
Filtration cannot separate sugar dissolved in ethanol, since both pass through the filter paper. Statement III is therefore incorrect.
This question is of medium difficulty, as it requires understanding both the practical safety concerns of laboratory techniques and the limitations of separation methods.

title: Question 19
content:
Which of the following correctly describes the properties of a homogeneous mixture?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The physical properties are uniform and the chemical properties of its components remain unchanged.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$The physical and chemical properties are those of its most abundant component.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$The physical and chemical properties are an average of the properties of its components.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$The physical properties vary throughout the sample, and its components do not retain their chemical properties.
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition and physical properties are uniform throughout the sample, and the chemical identity of each component remains unchanged.
Unlike a pure substance, a mixture's physical properties depend on the proportions and interactions of its components rather than on its most abundant component or a simple average.  Salt water is conductive while both pure water liquid and pure sodium chloride crystals are not.  Solder, a common alloy of tin and lead used in electronics, has a melting point of $183^\circ\text{C}$ while lead melts at 327$^\circ\text{C}$ and tin melts at 232$^\circ\text{C}.$ Again, solder does not take on the properties of the more abundant tin or have a melting point that is the average of its components.

title: Question 21
content:
A mixture is composed of wood chips, water, and sodium chloride. Which sequence of techniques could be used to isolate the wood chips and the sodium chloride separately?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Evaporation followed by paper chromatography
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration followed by paper chromatography
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Evaporation followed by solvation
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Filtration followed by evaporation
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To answer this question, the student must understand the properties of the mixture's components.
The wood chips would not dissolve in the water, so they are filtered out first. This will leave the sodium chloride dissolved in the water. The water can be evaporated to remove the water (to isolate the salt).
Paper chromatography would be ineffective in this scenario as it is used for separating substances such as dyes, pigments, and proteins.
This question is categorized as medium complexity because the student must understand the properties of matter and separation techniques.

title: Question 22
content: The melting point of benzene is $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$, and its boiling point is $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ - Draw the heating curve for benzene from $-10\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ to $110\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [3] - State the state of matter of benzene at $-6.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [1] - Describe the arrangement of benzene molecules at $50.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}.$ [2] - $5.00\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{NaCl}$ is added to $100\,\text{cm}^3$ of benzene. The salt is insoluble in the solvent. - Determine the type of mixture formed. [1] - Suggest a technique that can be applied to separate and recover benzene and sodium chloride. Sketch a labeled diagram to show how the separation will take place. [4]
markScheme:
- Temperature must be on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis; $\checkmark$
  Positive gradient from $-10.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ until $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and a flat section at $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$; $\checkmark$
  Positive gradient from $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ until $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and a flat section at $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ and positive gradient beyond $80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}$; $\checkmark$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e57860c-f4b3-4176-a0c6-7930fe46fdbe/images/fade02e5-06aa-4f09-b207-713810d89393/keep.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[© Revision Village 2023.]}}$
- solid. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  $-6.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ is below $5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$ (below the melting point).
- Any 2 of the following:
  Molecules close to one another (not in a regular pattern); $\checkmark$
  Molecules vibrating, rotating, and moving around; $\checkmark$
  Molecules can slide over each other. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  At $50.0\,{}^\circ\text{C}$, benzene is above the melting point ($5.5\,{}^\circ\text{C}$) and below the boiling point ($80.1\,{}^\circ\text{C}).$ Benzene is in the liquid state.
- 
  - Heterogeneous mixture. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    Sodium chloride is insoluble in benzene. The solid remains undissolved as a separate phase, and particles are not evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
  - Filtration. $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e57860c-f4b3-4176-a0c6-7930fe46fdbe/images/ee3fa417-9a36-439f-a815-0640036d5eb9/unnamed.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
    A funnel with filtering paper must be shown in the sketch; $\checkmark$
    Sodium chloride/residue in the filtering paper; $\checkmark$
    Benzene/filtrate shown. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}$:
    Sodium chloride is insoluble, and filtration allows the separation of a solid from a liquid by pouring the mixture through a paper filter. The solid is collected in the paper filter (residue), and the liquid goes through to be collected below (filtrate).

title: Question 28
content:
Which statement(s) is (are) correct about a pure substance?



- I.$\hspace{1.em}$It is always an element
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$Its melting point is sharp.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$More than one pure substance is present in a heterogeneous mixture.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Pure substances can be elements (for example, $\ce{O2})$ and/or compounds (for example, $\ce{H2O}).$ Statement I is incorrect.
Pure substances present a sharp melting point as they melt at a specific temperature. Statement II is correct.
Heterogeneous mixtures have a non-uniform composition made by different substances physically mixed together. Statement III is correct.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must understand what a pure substance is. They are also expected to recall the melting point as a technique applied to identify pure substances (as they have a sharp melting point) and clearly understand what heterogeneous mixtures are.

title: Question 31
content:
Paper chromatography is a technique that can be used to separate which of the following?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$A liquid and an insoluble solid
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Soluble solids
- C.$\hspace{1em}$A solid and an insoluble liquid
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Insoluble solids
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The student must correctly understand the process of paper chromatography. Components of a mixture can be successfully separated using paper chromatography only if the components are soluble in the mobile phase (the solvent). The components of the mixture can be liquids or solids when pure.
This question is categorized as medium because the student must understand that solubility in the mobile phase is essential for a successful separation using paper chromatography. Beyond that, there are no calculations or other facts to recall.

title: Question 34
content:
A solution of propan$-$1$-$ol and propan$-$2$-$ol must be separated. The full structural formulas of these are given below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/a60e3a4b-67bc-4abd-ae31-a49cda8a6d52/CH1095.png)


Which statement(s) is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Distillation allows the separation of the components of this mixture.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$A condenser, thermometer, and evaporating basin are needed for distillation.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$The distillate would be propan$-$2$-$ol.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Distillation is used to separate mixtures of miscible liquids with different boiling points, so Statement I is correct. The process involves heating the mixture until the more volatile liquid (the one with the lower boiling point) vaporizes, then condensing and collecting this vapor as the distillate. The less volatile component remains in the distillation flask.
Here is the typical setup:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/8bca4d25-da81-4aca-91e2-e91a58ca3eea/unnamed%20(1).png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
Statement II is incorrect because an evaporating basin is not used in distillation; the essential apparatus includes a distillation flask, a condenser, and a thermometer.
Statement III is correct because propan$-$2$-$ol has more branching than propan$-$1$-$ol, leading to weaker intermolecular forces and therefore a lower boiling point. This means propan$-$2$-$ol vaporizes and is collected first as the distillate.
This question is of moderate difficulty since it requires both knowledge of distillation as a separation technique and an understanding of how molecular structure affects boiling points.

title: Question 36
content:
A gas is placed in a sealed rigid container and heated. What happens to the gas particles according to the kinetic molecular theory?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$They move faster and collide more frequently with each other, but the pressure remains constant.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$They gain kinetic energy and move faster, increasing collisions with the container walls, which increases pressure.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$They expand within the container, increasing the density of the gas.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$They gain kinetic energy, but temperature remains constant as intermolecular forces are overcome.
markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
According to the kinetic molecular theory, when a gas is heated, the particles gain kinetic energy and move faster. Since the gas is in a sealed rigid container, the volume remains constant, meaning the only way for the gas to respond to heating is by increasing pressure. This happens because faster$\text{--}$moving particles collide more frequently and with greater force against the container walls, as described by Gay$\text{--}$Lussac's Law $(P\propto T$ at constant volume).

title: Question 38
content:
Which statement correctly describes the behavior of particles during the phase change from liquid to gas at the boiling point?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Particles remain in the liquid phase until the temperature exceeds the boiling point.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, causing a continuous rise in temperature.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, but the temperature remains constant.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Particles experience no change in energy while transitioning from liquid to gas.
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
During boiling, all heat energy supplied to the system is used to break intermolecular forces, allowing the substance to transition from liquid to gas. The kinetic energy of the particles does not increase, meaning the temperature remains constant until the phase change is complete. This is evident in a heating curve, where the plateau at the boiling point indicates that energy is being used for vaporization rather than raising temperature.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/036ac452-cb2a-430e-b1ac-408d86f09a5b/images/35fd9e9e-afe4-420e-9a46-4319fab8a71a/CH2082.png)

title: Question 39
content:
A sample of ethanol is placed in an open container. Over time, the volume of the liquid decreased, even though the temperature remained constant at 25$^\circ\text{C}.$
Select the statement that best describes this phenomenon.


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules at the surface vaporized at a temperature below boiling point.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol intermolecular forces are weaker at the surface, leading to vaporization.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules reached the boiling point and vaporized.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Ethanol molecules underwent a decrease in pressure, leading to vaporization.
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Evaporation occurs when molecules at the surface gain enough kinetic energy to overcome intermolecular forces and escape into the gas phase, even without reaching the boiling point. Unlike boiling, which requires the entire liquid to reach a specific temperature, evaporation happens gradually at any temperature.

title: Question 40
content:
During a calorimetry experiment, a student recorded the initial and final temperature of a sample in the table below:
Temperature /$^\circ$C$\\$ $\mathbf\pm 0.5^\circ$C$\ \ \ \ \ $Initial$\ \ \ \ \ $18.0Final72.0
What is the temperature change in Kelvin, including its uncertainty?


- A. $\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}$
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The correct answer is $54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}$ because the temperature change in Kelvin is equal to the temperature change in Celsius, meaning we simply subtract:
$72.0^\circ\text{C} - 18.0^\circ\text{C} = 54.0^\circ\text{C}$
The Kelvin scale is shifted by $273.15^\circ\text{C},$ but the degrees are the same size as Celsius degrees. Alternatively, both temperature can be converted to Kelvin before the subtraction
$345.15\text{ K} - 291.15\text{ K} = 54.0\text{ K}$
For the uncertainty, since we are subtracting two measured values, we must add their absolute uncertainties:
$(\pm 0.5\text{ K}) + (\pm 0.5\text{K}) = \pm 1.0\text{ K}$
This gives a final result of $54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}.$

title: Question 42
content:
A mixture is investigated through paper chromatography, comparing it with standards X, Y, and Z. The development of the chromatograph allows the interpretation of the results shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ce658891-f7b1-4bd2-8eca-c19f7241f8b4/images/08815fef-1bd2-442a-9d73-ea5db26ea175/CH1096.png)


Which statement(s) is(are) correct?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$X and Y are present in the mixture.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$Z is not present in the mixture
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$The mixture must contain four components.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$I, II, and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In paper chromatography, a solvent rises through the paper by capillary action and carries the components of a mixture with it. Different substances travel at different rates depending on their interactions with the paper and the solvent, producing a pattern of separated spots. The position of each spot can be expressed using the retention factor:
$R_f = \dfrac{\text{distance moved by the spot}}{\text{distance moved by the solvent front}}$
Retention factors range between 0 and 1 and provide a way to compare spots.
In the chromatogram, the mixture has separated into four distinct spots. The same $R_f$ value is seen in both the mixture and standard X, showing that X is present. Similarly, both spots of standard Y are also present in the mixture, so Y is included as well. Standard Z, however, has two spots not both present in the mixture, so Z is not included. Although four spots are visible in the mixture, this only proves that it contains at least four components$\text{---}$some spots may still contain more than one substance. Therefore, Statements I and II are correct, and Statement III is not.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall how chromatography works and interpret results for a specific case.

title: Question 10
content:
An atom has the nuclear symbol $\ce{^{35}_{17}X}.$ Which statement is correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 18 electrons.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$It has 18 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
markScheme:
B
`
$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
When identifying a isotope, the chemical symbol is written also
$\ce{_Z^A X}$
where $Z$ is the atomic number, or number of protons and $A$ is the mass number, thes sum of the number of protons and neutrons.
In the isotope $\ce{^{35}_{17}X},$ the atomic number is 17.  There are 17 protons in the nucleus. The mass number is 35. This is the sum of protons and neutrons. To find the number of neutrons, subtract the atomic number from the mass number: $35 - 17 = 18$ neutrons. Since this is a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, meaning it also has 17 electrons.

title: Question 15
content:
Which combination is correct for $\ce{^{41}_{19}K{^+}}?$
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
$\hspace{1.em}$Number of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsA.192218B.192220C.224120D.221918
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The nuclear symbol notation allows to deduce the number of protons, neutrons and electrons.
$\LARGE{_Z^A X^q}$X$\textrm{Chemical symbol}$ $\hspace{0.1em}$ $\mathbf{A}$Mass numberprotons + neutrons$\mathbf{Z}$Atomic numberprotons$\mathbf{q}$Chargeprotons $-$ electrons
In this symbol:


- $Z = 19$, the number of protons.
- $A=41$, there are $41 - 19 = 22$ neutrons.
- $q = +1$, there are $19-1=18$ electrons.

This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons by interpreting the nuclear symbol notation.

title: Question 16
content:
In a mass spectrum, the tallest peak is observed at $m/z = 40.$ Which of the following elements is most likely to produce this peak?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Ar
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Br
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ne
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Zr
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In mass spectrometry, the $m/z$ value represents the mass to charge ratio of an ion. Most ions formed in a mass spectrometer are singly charged (1+), so the $m/z$ value is equal to the mass number of the isotope. A peak at 40 suggests an ion with a mass of 40 and a charge of $+1.$ Argon has a common isotope, $\ce{^{40}Ar}$ in line with its relative atomic mass of 39.95.

title: Question 20
content:
Which isotope has the greatest number of neutrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^14_6C}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^16_8O}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^18_9F}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^20_10Ne}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The number of neutrons in an atom can be found using the following formula:
Mass number = # protons + # neutrons
In the isotopes written in this question, the top number is the mass number and the lower number is the atomic number which equals the number of protons. Therefore, the number of neutrons for each is:
IsotopeMass NumberAtomic NumberProtonsNeutrons$^14_6C $1466$14-6=8$ $^16_8O $1688$16-8=8$ $^18_9F $1899$18-9=9$ $^20_10Ne $201010$\mathbf{20-10=10}$

title: Question 26
content:
Which of the following mass spectra corresponds to chlorine?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$B.$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/d3b68f53-bcaa-41cb-85ae-807f4feca98d/CH2117a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/fad74a6e-a33e-4fa7-8ab3-155d219cc9f7/CH2117b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/015d691d-93ee-47ee-92dd-688e431e6582/CH2117c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/51050137-8d3a-498d-bc05-d7bb55253a60/CH2117d.png)
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The relative atomic mass of chlorine is listed as 35.45 on the periodic table. This value is a weighted average of the masses of chlorine's naturally occurring isotopes, based on their relative abundances. Since 35.45 is much closer to 35 than to 37, it suggests that the lighter isotope $(^{35}Cl)$ is more abundant than the heavier one $(^{37}Cl).$ In fact, chlorine exists as approximately 75% $(^{35}Cl)$ and 25% $(^{37}Cl).$ Therefore, the correct mass spectrum must show two peaks at $m/z = 35$ and 37, with the peak at 35 being roughly three times taller than the one at 37, matching the natural isotope distribution that results in a relative atomic mass of 35.45.

title: Question 27
content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following mass spectrum?
$\hspace{10 em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa9f46fc-be9a-4cfb-8873-f55b15040883/images/7324d25e-6103-4a9d-aa38-ffed61ee9688/CH1507.png)

$\hspace{10em}$


- A. $\hspace{1em}$150.50
- B. $\hspace{1em}$151.96
- C. $\hspace{1em}$152.00
- D. $\hspace{1em}$152.04
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To calculate the relative atomic mass of an element with two isotopes, we need to first read the relative abundance from the graph. The abundance of the isotope with mass 151 is 48%  and the isotope with mass 153 has an abundance of  52%. A 50:50 mix would yield an average mass of 152, since the 153 abundance is slightly higher, we expect the answer to be just more than 152.  Only one answer makes sense, 152.04.
To quantitatively solve for the relative average mass $(A_r),$ we will estimate the relative abundances and take the weighted average of the masses of the two isotopes.
$A_r =\dfrac{(151)(48) + (153)(52)}{100} = 152.04$
To solve without a calculator, rewrite 153 as $151 + 2$ in the equation above to find
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151+2)(52)}{100}$
Distributing yields
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151)(52) + (2)(52)}{100}$
Combine the first and second terms to find $(151)(48+52)$ or $(151)(100),$ so
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(100) + (2)(52)}{100}$ $A_r = 151 + \left(\dfrac{(2)(52)}{100}\right) = 151 + 1.04 = 152.04$

title: Question 29
content: Element Y has 4 stable isotopes. The table below shows the relative abundance and atomic masses of these isotopes. IsotopePercent abundanceAtomic mass11.40%203.97224.10%205.97322.10%206.98452.40%207.98 $\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$ - Calculate the relative atomic mass of the element. [2] - Identify the element. [1] - The atom of the element can form an ion with a charge of 4+. Determine the number of electrons in the ion. [1] - Determine the nuclear symbol of another corresponding ion of element Y given the numbers of subatomic particles: electrons = 80; neutrons = 122. [1]
markScheme:
- $A_r = (203.97) (0.014) + (205.97) (0.241)+ (206.98) (0.221) + (207.98)(0.524) \: \checkmark$
$A_r = 207.2 \: \checkmark$ 
$\textit{Award 2 marks for complete correct answer}$.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Relative atomic mass is the sum of each atomic mass of each isotope multiplied by its percentage abundance.
- Pb \ lead $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element with a relative atomic mass equal to 207.2 is lead.
- 78 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element is lead (Pb). Lead has an atomic number of 82. This means that a neutral atom of lead has 82 protons and 82 electrons. Its atom loses 4 electrons $(82-4)$ and becomes a cation with a charge of $4+$, $\ce{Pb^{4+}}.$
- Nuclear symbol: $\ce{^{204}_{82}Pb^{2+}}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
There are 80 electrons in the corresponding ion. This means that the atom has lost 2 electrons and has a become an ion of charge 2+.
  Mass number = protons + neutrons = $82 + 122 = 204$

title: Question 30
content:
An element X has a relative atomic mass of 21.25.
Which mass spectrum corresponds to the isotopic composition of X?


- A.B.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/b0f297d5-de02-4d19-9f8e-aba47a085fa2/CH1249a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/85cc2686-44c7-4fc4-829e-caa5bf3d8634/CH1249b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/65ba8959-0722-4060-81f2-d7e431903fb7/CH1249c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/1cf0441e-3b60-41ab-8de6-0e574e270db3/CH1249d.png)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The relative atomic mass of an element is calculated as the weighted mean of the isotope masses, using their percentage abundances. For spectrum A, the calculation is:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (21 \times 25) + (22 \times 50)}{100} =  21.25$
This matches the value given in the question.
For comparison:
Spectrum B:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 10) + (21 \times 10) + (22 \times 80)}{100} =  21.70$
Spectrum C:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 90) + (21 \times 5) + (22 \times 5)}{100} =  20.15$
Spectrum D:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (22 \times 75)}{100} =  21.50$
This question is of medium difficulty because it tests the ability to apply the weighted mean formula systematically and also to reason qualitatively about how the distribution of isotopes shifts the average mass.

title: Question 38
content: Nickel has five stable isotopes. The masses and percent abundances are tabulated below: IsotopePercent abundance$^{58}$Ni68.08%$^{60}$Ni26.22%$^{61}$Ni1.14%$^{62}$NiA$^{64}$NiB - The relative atomic mass of nickel is 58.745, calculate the percent abundance of nickel$\text{--}$62 and nickel$\text{--}$64. [3] - State the number of protons and neutrons in nickel$\text{--}$62. [1] - Using your results from part (a), sketch the mass spectrum of nickel. [3]
markScheme:
- $58(68.08)+ 60(26.22) + 61(1.14)+ 62A+ 64B = 58.745(100)\ \checkmark$
  $A + B = 100 - (68.08 + 26.22 + 1.14) = 4.56\ \checkmark$
  $A = 4.36$ AND $B = 0.19\ \checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  The weighted average of the isotopes must be equal to the relative atomic mass of nickel, 58.74.
  $58.745 = \dfrac{(58)(68.08) + (60)(26.22) + (61)(1.14) + 62A + 64B}{100}$
  and the sum of the percent abundances must be 100.
  $68.08 + 26.22 + 1.14 + A + B = 100$
  Solving these two equations and two unknowns will give $A$ and $B.$ From equation 2,
  $A + B = 4.56\quad$ or $\quad B = 4.56 - A$
  Plugging that in to equation 1,
  $5874.5 = 5591.38 + 62A + 64(4.56 - A)$
  Solving for $A$ and $B$ give:
  $A = 4.36$ and $B = 0.20$
- protons: 28 AND neutrons:
  $62 - 28 = 34\ \checkmark$
- $\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/601d52e5-637f-40a8-a317-f72d356818d1/images/e9bf53d1-b776-4c7f-9e98-4b9091d034a8/CH2113v2.png)


  Correct atomic masses for each isotope $\checkmark$
  Correct relative peak heights $\checkmark$
  Proper labeling of axes: $x\text{--}$axis: $m/z$ or atomic mass AND $y\text{--}$axis: relative abundance or intensity $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  A mass spectrum shows how many atoms of each isotope are present in a sample of an element, based on their mass$\text{--to--}$charge ratio $(m/z).$ Each line represents an isotope assuming a $+1$ charge. The height of the line corresponds to its abundance.

title: Question 40
content:
A sample of chlorine gas contains the isotopes $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{37}Cl}$. In the mass spectrum of a sample of chlorine gas, what is an interpretation of the peak at 74 $m/z$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- B. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- C. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting of $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- D. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of two $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The student must understand that in the mass spectrum of chlorine gas, there is more than one peak present and it consists of the combinations of molecules and atoms from the isotopes:


- $\ce{^{35}Cl^+}$ at 35 $m/z$
- $\ce{^{37}Cl^+}$ at 37 $m/z$
- $\ce{^{35}Cl_2^+}$ at 70 $m/z$ (composed of two $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms: 35 + 35 = 70)
- $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ $\ce{^{37}Cl^+}$ at 72 $m/z$ (composed of $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms: 35 + 37 = 72)
- $\ce{^{37}Cl_2^+}$ at 74 $m/z$ (composed of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms: 37 + 37 = 74)

This question is categorized as difficult because the student must interpret the mass spectrum data correctly based on the possible combinations from the chlorine isotopes.

title: Question 1
content:
What is the maximum number of electrons in the $4p$ subshell?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 6
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 10
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 2
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 8
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For $p$, $l$ is equal to 1. The number of electrons in a given subshell can be calculated using the formula:
$2(2\,l + 1) = 2((2)(1) + 1) = 6$ electrons
The $p$ subshell holds 3 orbitals. Each orbital can fit 2 electrons. Therefore, $p$ subshell holds 6 electrons.

title: Question 2
content:
What is the electron configuration of this orbital diagram?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/aebba581-d5ec-4940-850d-7777dc859933/CH0262.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2p^3\,2s^2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^3\,2p^2$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $1s^2\,2s^2\,3s^3$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The orbital diagram shows two electrons in the $1s$ orbital, two in the $2s$ orbital, and three singly placed in the $2p$ orbitals. This adds up to seven electrons, which is the electron count for nitrogen in its ground state. According to the Aufbau principle, the 1s orbital is filled first, followed by $2s,$ and then $2p.$ The Pauli exclusion principle requires that each orbital holds no more than two electrons with opposite spin, and Hund's rule explains why the three $2p$ electrons occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before any pairing occurs.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/566bc402-15c8-4c3e-ad06-0370a9a3d480/CH0262ms.png)

title: Question 5
content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration of a typical sodium ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^2$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{[Ne]}\, 2s^1$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number of sodium is 11. Its electron configuration follows the Aufbau principle, filling the electron sublevels from lowest to highest energy.
$\ce{Na}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^1$
This can be rewritten in noble gas or shorthand notation by observing that the noble gas neon has the same core electron filling $(\ce{Ne}:\, 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6)$.  The electron configuration of neutral sodium can be rewritten as
$\ce{Na}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]\,3s^1$
The atom loses one electron to become a stable ion with a charge of 1+ (10 electrons). The removed electron is from the valence shell (the $3s$ electron).  The electron configuration of sodium ion is
$\ce{Na^+}$:$ \ [\ce{Ne}]$
Alternatively, notice that sodium ion is isoelectronic with neon so mush share its electron configuration.

title: Question 8
content:
Which equation represents the second ionization energy for $\ce{Cu}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^{2+}(g) -> Cu^{3+}(g) + e^-}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^+(g) -> Cu^{2+}(g) + e^-}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^{2+}(g) + e^- -> Cu^+(g)}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu(g) -> 2 e^- + Cu^{2+}(g)}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.

title: Question 9
content: Cobalt is an important cofactor that often inhibits enzyme activity involved in cellular respiration, such as catalase. - Using the complete electron configuration, determine the electron configuration of $\ce{Co^2+}.$ [1] - Draw the orbital diagram of the $3d$ electrons of $\ce{Co}$. [1]
markScheme:
- $\ce{Co^2+: 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^7}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Electron configuration of $\ce{Co}$: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$ ; the $4s$ electrons are lost.
- $\mbox{}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f5e00a3-3776-40e9-ab47-f0197c289615/images/934ccb2e-c8ae-49f8-b381-4b19b75e2df6/2.2-267.png)


$\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  The last shell of $\ce{Co}$ contains 2 electrons in the $4s$ subshell and 7 electrons in the $3d$ subshell.

title: Question 10
content:
Which statements about the hydrogen emission spectrum are correct?


- I.The lines converge at higher energiesII.The lines converge at higher frequenciesIII.The lines converge at higher wavelengths



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The lines converge as energy levels increase (increased distance from the nucleus).
Higher energies result in higher frequencies.

title: Question 11
content: The successive ionization energies of an atom are as shown on the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6be37a74-4c6e-4a6c-b3d4-ff940ed880dc/images/205aa233-c6fe-4aa8-914e-cd160fb89c56/CH1083_Image1.png) $\small{\textrm{[Data source: Kramida, A., Ralchenko, Yu., Reader, J., and NIST ASD Team (2022). NIST Atomic Spectra Database (ver. 5.10),}}\\ \small{\textrm{ [Online]. Available: https://physics.nist.gov/asd [2023, August 30]. National Institute of Standards and Technology,}}\\ \small{\textrm{Gaithersburg, MD. DOI: https://doi.org/10.18434/T4W30F)]}}$ - State which group this atom belongs to. [1] - Write the ground state electron configuration for the first ion formed. [1]
markScheme:
- Group 1: $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The gap between $IE_1$ and $IE_2$ is quite large, suggesting that the element belongs to group $1$ with one valence electron.
- $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6 \ \checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The atom has 11 electrons.  The ground state electron configuration is $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1$. The first electron is lost from the $3s$ orbital; thus, the ground state electron configuration for the first ion formed is $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6.$

title: Question 13
content: Hydrogen exhibits two emission lines, $D1$ and $D2$. $D1$ has a wavelength of $656 \textrm{\ nm}$ and $D2$ has a frequency of $6.17\times 10^{14}\textrm{\ s}^{-1}$. - Calculate the frequency of the $D1$ emission line of hydrogen. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of the $D2$ emission line of hydrogen. [1] - Compare the two emission lines, and using the IB Chemistry data booklet, suggest which of the emission lines is most likely to be red. [2]
markScheme:
- The frequency of $D1$ emission line of hydrogen:
  $\begin{aligned}
  f &= \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{656 \textrm{\ nm} \times \frac{1\textrm{\ m}}{1 \times 10^9 \textrm{\ nm}}} \\
  f &= \answer{4.57 \times 10^{14} \textrm{ s}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \textrm{Rearranging the formula:}\ c &= \lambda f, \\
  \textrm{We obtain:}\  f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The wavelength of the $D2$ emission line of hydrogen:
  $\begin{aligned}
  \lambda &=\dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{6.17 \times 10^{14} \textrm{\ s}^{-1}}  \\
  \lambda &= 4.86\times 10^{-7} \textrm{\ m} \times \dfrac{1\textrm{\ m}}{1 \times 10^9 \textrm{\ nm}} = \answer{486 \textrm{\ nm}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \textrm{Rearranging the formula:}\ c &= \lambda f, \\
  \textrm{We\ obtain:}\ \lambda &=\dfrac{c}{f}  \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The frequency $D2 > D1$ and the wavelength $D1 > D2$; $\checkmark$
  $D1$ with the larger wavelength and smaller frequency is more likely to be on the red end of the visible spectrum. $\checkmark$

title: Question 14
content:
Which statement about ionization energies is $\textbf{incorrect}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ First ionization energies are always higher than second ionization energies
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ It represents the energy required to remove electrons
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The general trend is that first ionization energies increase across a period
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The general trend is that first ionization energies decrease down a group
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Second ionization energies are higher than the first as the electrons are being removed from a positive ion resulting in a stronger electrostatic attraction.
First ionization energies do increase across a period due to increasing nuclear charge.
First ionization energies also decrease down a group due to increased shielding (number of shells).

title: Question 15
content: - - State the full electron configurations of an $\ce{N}$ atom and $\ce{O}$ atom. [2] - Draw the orbital diagrams for an $\ce{N}$ atom and $\ce{O}$ atom. [2] - Compare and explain the difference between the first ionization energy of oxygen and nitrogen. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - N: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^3$ $\checkmark$ 
O: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^4$ $\checkmark$

$\checkmark \checkmark$ $\hspace{2.in}$

paired electron in $2p-$sublevel experiences increased e$-$e repulsion  $\checkmark$

title: Question 17
content:
Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?


- I.The emission spectra are produced from a release of energy of excited electronsII.No two electrons in one atom have the same set of quantum numbersIII.The electrons in an orbital must have an opposite spin



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement I is true because emission spectra are produced when photons are released from excited electrons returning to lower energy levels.
Statement II is true because this is Pauli's Exclusion principle.
Statement III is also true because it is included in Pauli's Exclusion principle.

title: Question 18
content: Scandium is a transition metal that can form both $2+$ and $3+$ complexes. - Draw the electron in boxes notation for the $4s$ and $3d$ electrons in an $\ce{Sc^2+}$ ion. [1] - State the equation for the third ionization energy of scandium, and indicate which electron is lost. [2] - Explain why $\ce{[Sc(H2O)6]^2+}$ is coloured whereas $\ce{[Sc(H2O)6]^3+}$ forms a colourless aqueous solution. [3]
markScheme:
- $\checkmark$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b12c1f6-c260-4b3f-9804-66292bb8611b/images/90adbde8-b665-429f-953b-4d0b05cc1772/CH0403.png)



  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  $\ce{Sc}$ has the electron configuration $\ce{[Ar]}\,3d^1\,4s^2$. Two $4s$ electrons are lost to form the $2+$ ion.
- $\ce{Sc^2+(g) -> Sc^3+(g) + e-} \,\checkmark$
$\textit{State symbols required for mark}$
  The $3d^1$ electron. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
  Third ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous $2+$ ions.

title: Question 20
content:
What is the ground state electron configuration of an atom of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table?


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^4$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^6$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To identify the electron configuration of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table, we need to find the configuration that ends with $ns^2\ np^4$
Let's examine each given configuration:
ConfigurationValence ElectronsGroupElement$2s^2\ 2p^2$414C$2s^2\ 2p^4$616O$4s^2\ 3d^6$88Fe$4s^2\ 4p^6$818Kr

title: Question 23
content: Each element contains a different arrangement of electrons, and these electron configurations can also be represented using orbital diagrams. Determine the identity of each element described below. - $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1$ [1] - $\ce{[Ne] }3s^2\,3p^6$ [1] - In Period 3 with valence electrons of 3$s^2$ [1] - An element with electron configuration ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28b09a53-c289-460a-8566-78a2419e5fac/images/833703a9-e874-4501-9424-4af7dad37294/ch0263d-new.png) [1] - An ion with 1+ charge, with valence electrons of![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28b09a53-c289-460a-8566-78a2419e5fac/images/28088b14-f7f5-479b-ad6a-5c2480eb22b2/ch0263e-new.png) [1]
markScheme:
- $\ce{Potassium (K)}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: number of electrons $\,= 19$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 19 \rightarrow \text{Potassium}$
  Method 2: $4s^1$ shows that element is in group 1 and period 4 $\rightarrow$ Potassium
- $\ce{Argon (Ar)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: group 18 (8 valence electrons) and period 3 (n = 3) $\rightarrow$ Argon
  Method 2: number of electrons$\,= 18$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 18 \rightarrow \text{Argon}$
- $\ce{Magnesium (Mg)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: period 3 and group 2 ( 2 valence electrons on 3s$^2$) → Magnesium.
  Method 2: Electron configuration should be 1$s^2 2$s^2 2$p^6$ 3$s^2$. A total of 12 electrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z =$ number of protons = 12 → Magnesium
- $\ce{ Fluorine (F) }$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: number of electrons $= 9$. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z= \text{number of protons} = 9 \rightarrow \text{Fluorine}$
  Method 2: period 2 (n = 2) and group 17 (7 valence electrons) $\rightarrow$ Fluorine
- $\ce{Sodium (Na)}$  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Method 1: Electron configuration of the ion: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6$
  Electron configuration of the atom: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1$
  n = 3 (period 3) and 1 valence electron (group 1) $\rightarrow$ Sodium.
  Method 2: Electron configuration of the ion: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6$
  Electron configuration of the atom: $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1$.
  A total of 11 electrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons. Therefore, $Z$ = number of protons = 11 $\rightarrow$ Sodium

title: Question 24
content:
In an atom with many electrons, which set of orbitals is arranged in order of lowest electron energy to highest electron energy?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2p, 3d, 4s, 4p$
- B.$\hspace{1em}4s, 2p, 4p, 3d$
- C.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 3d, 4p$
- D.$\hspace{1em}2p, 4s, 4p, 3d$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electrons fill sublevels according to the Aufbau Principle shown below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c0a4e08-133c-402d-8e75-db2d84192445/images/cbfc092e-d8aa-4e64-9b84-a94c1674e5b6/CH0775.png)


Following this order, $2p < 4s < 3d < 4p$

title: Question 33
content: Manganese presents a variety of oxidation states. - Deduce the number of electrons in $\ce{Mn^2+}.$ [1] - Annotate the diagram below showing $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals for $\ce{Mn^2+}$ using an arrow to represent the electron. [1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/5187fdb0-7f67-4f43-8bea-03f13ed342a2/unnamed%20(20).png) - Deduce the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Mn^7+}.$ [1]
markScheme:
- 23 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 2 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ has 23 electrons.
- $\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$
  $\ \ \ \  \ $![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/edb5877a-7379-4264-85a7-bb23f06e6b0a/images/beef272b-28c3-4a37-8177-6591746d64ea/unnamed%20(21).png)

$\checkmark$
  Do not penalize the omission of the $4s$ orbital.
- $\ce{[Ar]}$ OR $\ce{[Ne]}3s^2\,3p^6\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Mn has 25 electrons. It loses 7 electrons, so $\ce{Mn^7+}$ has 18 electrons. If we apply the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle, its electronic configuration turns out to be $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6.$

title: Question 34
content:
Which species have the same electron configuration?


- I.Ni, Cu$^+$, Zn$^{2+}$II.$^{12}$C, $^{13}$C, $^{14}$CIII.O$^{2-}$, F$^-$, Ne



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement II is correct as isotopes only differ in the number of neutrons.
Statement III is correct as they are all isoelectronic with Ne (full valence shell).
At first glance, Statement I may look correct as they all have the same number of electrons. However, since they are transition metals, we must consider how the electrons are arranged in the  $4s$ and $3d$ orbitals.
Ni has an electron configuration of [Ar] $4s^2\,3d^8$ whereas Cu$^+$ and Zn$^{2+}$ have electron configurations of [Ar] $3d^{10}$, remembering that copper is an exception and that $4s$ electrons are removed before $3d$ electrons in ions.  Statement I is incorrect.

title: Question 35
content:
Which atoms' orbital diagram does this figure represent?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f476c2e5-1379-4cbc-9583-33c80808e480/images/5ddeef50-9182-4ed9-8ebe-f191c34ff22a/2.2-260.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{C}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{O}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{N}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{F}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The number of arrows denotes the number of electrons the atom has. The orbital diagram shown here has 8 arrows which tells you that there are 8 electrons.
Choice A  is not correct because C has only 6 electrons.
Choice D is also not correct because F has 9 electrons.
Choice C is incorrect as N has 7 electrons.
Among the choices, oxygen in its neutral form has 8 electrons. Hence, choice B is the correct answer.

title: Question 38
content:
Which statement about the first ionization energies for the elements in period 3 is incorrect?


- A. $\hspace{1em}P$ has a lower first ionization energy than $S$ because $S$ has more protons
- B. $\hspace{1em}S$ has a lower first ionization energy than P because S has greater $e^- -e^-$ repulsion
- C. $\hspace{1em}Na$ has the lowest first ionization energy
- D. $\hspace{1em}Ar$ has the highest first ionization energy
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Generally, the first ionization energy increases across a period (due to the decrease in atomic radius and the increase in nuclear charge). In period 3, Na is the first element with the lowest ionization energy, and Ar is the last element with the highest ionization energy.
There are some exceptions to the trend. Phosphorus (1012 kJ mol$^{-1}$) has a higher ionization energy than sulfur (1000 kJ/mol), despite sulfur being further right on the periodic table.
To understand this exception, we can consider the electron configuration for S,  $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^4$, and P, $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^3$. In sulfur, one orbital contains paired electrons, increasing electron-electron repulsion. This repulsion lowers sulfur's ionization energy by making it easier to remove an electron, despite its higher nuclear charge.

title: Question 39
content:
Which of the following species has the highest number of unpaired electrons?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{2+}}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{3+}}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{6+}}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Chromium is one of the exceptions to completely filling the 4$s$ orbital before the 3$d$ orbital.
It has an electron configuration of $[Ar] 4s^1  3d^5$ and all six valence electrons are unpaired. As electrons are removed to form chromium ions, the number of unpaired electrons decreases. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

title: Question 40
content: $\ce{^{63}Cu}$ and $\ce{^{65}Cu}$ are the two most abundant isotopes of copper. - - Define isotope. [1] - Determine the correct numbers of subatomic particles to complete the following table. [1] - Copper-63Copper-65Number of protonsNumber of electronsNumber of neutrons - Calculate the relative abundances of $\ce{^{63}Cu}$ and $\ce{^{65}Cu}$ using section 6 (Section 7- 2025 Syllabus) of the data booklet. [3] - Complete the orbital diagram for the valence electrons in a copper atom and a copper (II) ion. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/f470055e-fefe-474a-8407-420630894d44/CH0684b.png)
markScheme:
- 
  - Isotopes of an element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers / same number of protons but a different number of neutrons. $\checkmark$
  - All correct $\checkmark$
    
    
    - Copper-63Copper-65Number of protons2929Number of electrons2929Number of neutrons3436

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The number of protons for both isotopes is the same as the atomic number of copper. Since both isotopes are electrically neutral, the number of electrons is the same as the number of protons. The number of neutrons is calculated by subtracting the number of protons from the mass number.
  - Let $x$ be the relative abundance of copper-63. Using the data booklet, the relative atomic mass of copper is 63.55.
    $\dfrac{63x+65\left(100-x\right)}{100} = 63.55\quad \Longrightarrow \quad -2x = -145\,\checkmark$
    Relative abundance of copper-63: $x=72.5\%$ $\checkmark$
    Relative abundance of copper-65: $100-x=100-72.5=27.5\%$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The relative atomic mass is calculated by finding the weighted average of the isotopes. This means we can find the relative abundances if we know the relative atomic mass of copper and the isotopes of copper.
    We know that the relative abundances of the two isotopes must add up to 100$\%$ so we can set the abundance of copper-63 as a variable $x$ and the abundance of copper-65 as $100-x$. We can set up an equation with these abundances and the isotopic masses and rearrange to solve for $x$. With $x$, we can then calculate the individual abundances.

- All arrow correct for each of Cu and Cu$^{2+}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/c82d90ce-ffac-4589-bfed-d237efe0d33e/CH0684b-MS.png)


  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Copper is one of the exceptions to having the 4s orbital completely filled before filling the 3d orbital $-$ it has an electron configuration of [Ar] $4s^1\,3d^{10}$. When removing electrons to form cations, the 4s electrons are removed before the 3d electrons so the copper (II) ion has an electron configuration of  [Ar] $3d^9$. When drawing the orbital diagrams, remember that each orbital can only fit two electrons of opposite spin and each degenerate 3d orbital is first singly filled before pairing the electrons up.

title: Question 41
content: $\ce{Cu}$ is a transition metal commonly used in wires. - Determine the complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$. [1] - State the condensed electron configuration of $\ce{Cu+}.$ [1] - Determine whether the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ follows the usual rules of electron configuration. [1]
markScheme:
- Longhand/complete electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$
  $\ce{1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^{10} 4s^1}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\ce{Cu}$ is one of the exceptions where a $3d$ orbital would fill before $4s$ and this is due to the fact that a full $3d$ orbital is more stable.
- Condensed electron configuration
  $\ce{[Ar]\,3d^{10}}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  1 electron lost from $4s$ orbital (highest energy level).
- There is an anomaly with the electron configuration of $\ce{Cu}$ simply because there is slightly greater stability associated with the fully filled ($3d^{10}$) subshell than the incomplete one. Hence, the $3d^{10}$ is filled first before pairing the $4s$ subshell. $\checkmark$
