title: Question 43
content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom would produce the shortest wavelength?


- A.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 1s$
- B.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 2s$
- C.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 3s$
- D.$\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 4s$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The shortest wavelength corresponds to a higher frequency and therefore a higher energy transition. The $5p$ to $1s$ represents the largest energy drop and therefore would produce the shortest wavelength.

title: Question 44
content:
An electron in a hydrogen atom transitions from $n = 1$  to $n = 4$, which statement below best describes the energy involved in this transition?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is absorbed in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is emitted in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is absorbed in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Energy is emitted in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Transitions from energy levels $n = 2, 3, 4\ldots$ to $n = 1$ represent the largest energy transitions due to the convergence of energy levels moving away from the nucleus.
A transition from $n = 4 \longrightarrow n = 1$  emits in the UV range of the spectrum. Since the proposed transition is from $n = 1$ to $n = 4$, ultraviolet light is absorbed rather than emitted.

title: Question 45
content: John is sitting on a beach on a warm summer evening watching the reddish sky ($\lambda=650$ nm) while his brother, Eric, is playing with his laser beam with a frequency of $4.60\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}$. - Calculate the frequency of the radiation from the red sky. [1] - Calculate the wavelength of the laser beam of Eric. [1] - Compare the wavelength of the laser beam with the wavelength of the radiation of the red sky. [1] - Deduce the colour of the laser beam of Eric. [1]
markScheme:
- $\begin{aligned}
  \\
  f &= \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{650\times 10^{-9}\,\text{m}} \\
  f &= \answer{4.62\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \text{Rearranging the formula: } c &= \lambda f, \\
  \text{We obtain: } f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- $\begin{aligned}
  \\
  \lambda &= \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{4.60\times 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}} \\
  \lambda &= \answer{652\,\text{nm}}\,\checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $\begin{aligned}
  \text{Rearranging the formula: } c &= \lambda f, \\
  \text{We obtain: } f &= \dfrac{c}{\lambda} \\
  \end{aligned}$
- The wavelength of the laser beam and the red sky is almost the same, which is 650 nm vs 652 nm. $\checkmark$
- Since the laser beam and red sky have a very similar wavelength, the colour of the laser beam is also red. $\checkmark$

title: Question 48
content:
An element has the electron configuration $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^7$. Which of the below gives this element the correct number of energy levels, block, and group?


- Energy levelsBlockGroupA.$\hspace{1em}$3$s$2B.$\hspace{1em}$3$d$7C.$\hspace{1em}$4$s$7D.$\hspace{1em}$4$d$9
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This highest principal energy level is 4 ($4s^2$).
The subshell being filled is $3d$, making it a $d-$block element. Its position in the $d-$block and the total number of valence electrons, being 9 ($4s^2 + 3d^7$), places this element in group 9.

title: Question 51
content:
Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Al$^+$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Zn
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ca
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Sc$^{3+}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Electron configuration of Al$^+$: [Ne] $3s^2$
Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^{10}$
Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar] $4s^2$
Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar] $4s^2$ $3d^1$.
Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc$^{3+}$ ($1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6$).

title: Question 54
content:
How many fully occupied $p$ orbitals are present in a ground$\text{--}$state arsenic (As) atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$2
- B. $\hspace{1em}$3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$6
- D. $\hspace{1em}$7
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filled $p$ subshells, or 6 filled $p$ orbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is  $[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.$ Hund's rule reminds us that the three valence $p$ electrons in arsenic will singly$\text{--}$occupy the three $4p$ orbitals. There will be 6 fully occupied $p$ orbitals.

title: Question 55
content:
Which electrons are lost in the formation of a copper (II)  ion from a copper atom?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$One $3s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- B. $\hspace{1em}$One $4s$ electron and one $3d$ electron
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Two $4s$ electrons
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Two $3d$ electrons
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\ce{Cu}$ has the electron configuration $\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1\,3d^{10}$ (a full d-subshell is more stable). The $4s$ electron is lost in the first ionization followed by a $3d$ electron.

title: Question 56
content:
How many unpaired electrons are in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$3
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1
- D.$\hspace{1em}$2
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configuration
Mn: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^5$
according to the aufbau principle.  When transition metals lose electrons, they lose them from the sublevel with the highest $n-$level.  For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the $4s$ sublevel to form the ion $\ce{Mn^2+}$.
$\ce{Mn^{2+}}$: $1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^5$
To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e265c959-7bc9-4194-ba46-8554199f8bb3/images/9a9bc6c8-e8b3-49c5-af73-68b3320ed6a3/CH0777.png)


There are five unpaired electrons in the $\ce{Mn^{2+}}$ ion.

title: Question 58
content:
Which of the following is the correct electron configuration for iron in $\ce{FeCl2}?$


- A. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6$
- B. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^4$
- C. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\  3d^6$
- D. $\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^8$
markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The ground$\text{--}$state electron configuration of neutral iron is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6.$ In $\ce{FeCl2},$ iron has a $2+$ charge so two electrons are removed from the iron atom. In transition metals, electrons are removed from the $4s$ sublevel first, not $3d,$ even though $4s$ is filled before $3d.$
Therefore, $\ce{Fe^2+}$ has the configuration $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 3d^6.$

title: Question 59
content:
Which gives the correct electron configuration for the chromium atom, Cr, and the chromium cation, $\ce{Cr+}$?


- CrCr$\mathbf{^+}$A.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$B.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^1$C.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^4 4s^2$[Ar] $3d^3 4s^2$D.$\hspace{1em}$[Ar] $3d^5 4s^1$[Ar] $3d^5$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Chromium is an exception to the rule for the first$-$row $d-$block elements due to the stability of a half$-$filled $d-$subshell. When forming a positive ion, electrons are first lost from $4s$ and then $3d$.

title: Question 60
content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energy data for an unknown metal M.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/52199042-cddb-421f-b65d-11e90428d392/images/555bf712-15ca-47f4-8685-1f60dc9bef9a/CH1251.png)


What is the likely formula of the oxide formed with this metal?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{MO}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{MO_2}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O_3}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The graph shows a large jump after the removal of the first electron, which indicates that this metal has just one valence electron. This places it in group 1 of the periodic table. In group 1 metals, the second electron lies in an inner energy level, much closer to the nucleus and much more difficult to remove, which explains the sudden increase in ionization energy.
A group 1 metal forms a monovalent cation, $\ce{M^+}$, which bonds ionically with oxide, $\ce{O^{2-}}$. To achieve charge balance, two $\ce{M^+}$ ions combine with one $\ce{O^{2-}}$, giving the formula $\ce{M2O}$.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must deduce the group of the metal to figure out the formula of the compound formed with oxygen.

title: Question 61
content: - On the axis below, sketch the trend in first ionization energies for the elements in the second period. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9b45cc58-e523-4f52-864e-eae23e608867/images/f1506e00-a0e4-493b-9ce0-8aeaf0b1d48e/CH0601.png) - - Explain the general trend in first ionization energies. [2] - Predict whether the first ionization energies for the third period elements will be higher, lower or the same as their respective elements in the second period. [1]
markScheme:
- $\mbox{}$
  
  
  - ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9b45cc58-e523-4f52-864e-eae23e608867/images/2eab7790-1276-4d2c-be9c-c2ceae5ab875/CH0601-1.png)


   

  $\textit{General increasing trend}\, \checkmark$
$\textit{Drop between Be and B}\,\checkmark$
$\textit{Drop between N and O}\,\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  More electron-electron repulsion in O (easier to remove the first electron).
  It is easier to remove the electron from the 2p$_x$ orbital in B since 2p is higher in energy than 2s in Be.
- 
  - The first ionization energy increases. $\checkmark$
    Same shielding AND increasing nuclear charge. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    The valence electrons are in the same energy level where there is no change in/additional shielding. Since the nuclear charge increases, there is a higher force of attraction, and more energy is required.
  - Lower. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
    As electrons are further from the nucleus, with additional shells and therefore shielding, there is a reduced electrostatic force of attraction between the nucleus and the outermost electrons.

title: Question 63
content: [Maximum marks: 10] Magnesium is an element in group 2 of the periodic table. - State the full electron configuration for magnesium and the block it can be found in the periodic table. [2] - Explain how successive ionization energies can prove that magnesium is in group 2 and period 3 of the periodic table. [3] - State the equation for the second ionization energy of magnesium. [1] - State an equation for the reaction between magnesium oxide and water, and comment on the pH of the resultant solution. [2] - By referring to their relative ionization energies, compare the metallic behavior of magnesium to calcium and beryllium (values from the data booklet are not required). [2]
markScheme:
- $1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2$; $\checkmark$
  $s$ (block). $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The $3s$ subshell is the highest energy subshell placing magnesium in the $s$-block.
- Group 2: Large increase in energy between 2$^{nd}$ and 3$^{rd}$ ionization energies shows that there are two electrons in the outermost shell. $\checkmark$
  Period 3: Two significant increases in energy (between 2$^{nd}$ and 3$^{rd}$, and 10$^{th}$ and 11$^{th}$ ionization energies) shows that there are three distinct energy levels. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Large increases in ionization energy suggest an electron is being removed from an energy level closer to the nucleus.
- $\ce{Mg+(g) -> Mg^2+(g) + e-}\,\checkmark$
  State symbols required
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  The second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous singly positive ions. This equation follows from the first ionization energy definition, which must be known.
- $\ce{MgO(s) + H2O(l) -> Mg(OH)2(aq)}\,\checkmark$
  State symbols NOT required
  pH greater than 7 $\checkmark$
  ALLOW any value greater than 7
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Metallic hydroxides are basic.
- Calcium is more metallic than magnesium, AND beryllium is less metallic than magnesium $\checkmark$
  Ionization energies decrease down group 2 $\checkmark$
  Metals have a greater tendency to lose electrons OR are more easily oxidized OWTTE $\checkmark$

title: Question 64
content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.
Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

title: Question 71
content:
The figure shows the visible line emission spectrum of hydrogen.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/3c917e33-7871-4db3-92fb-7ba883f0f5f8/CH2146.png)


Which of the following transitions is most likely responsible for the red line in the spectrum?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n = 5\longrightarrow n = 2$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n = 2\longrightarrow n = 1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n = 4\longrightarrow n = 2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n = 3\longrightarrow n = 2$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The red line marked in the figure is the longest-wavelength of the four visible lines and must come from the smallest energy drop that ends at the second energy level. Of the options given, the transition from $n = 3$ down to $n = 2$ fits that description: it releases less energy than drops from $n = 4$ or $n = 5$ to $n = 2,$ so its photon has a longer wavelength and appears red. The $n = 2 \longrightarrow n = 1$ transition is ruled out because it ends at the first level and produces ultraviolet light, which is not visible in the spectrum shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/058442e4-9a9f-423c-b942-81f41aad4b2c/CH2146ans.JPEG)

title: Question 72
content:
The table below shows the successive ionization energies of two elements X and Y.
Number of electrons $\newline$ removedIonization energy of X $\newline$ / kJ mol$\mathbf{^{-1}}$Ionization energy of Y $\newline$ / kJ mol$\mathbf{^{-1}}$149610002456222523691033574954345565133547004616613849672011727107
Which is the correct formula for the compound formed between X and Y?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The student must deduce the corresponding group of elements X and Y from the successive ionization energies given. An element's successive ionization energies increase as more energy is needed to remove electrons.  As the ion becomes more positive, it will take more energy to remove the next electron.  Successive ionization energies always increase. When the next electron is in a shell closer to the nucleus, the successive ionization energy will increase sharply because there is less shielding of the nuclear charge and because the distance between the electron and nucleus is smaller.
In the table provided, the largest jump in the ionization energy for element X occurs between $IE_1$ (first ionization energy) and $IE_2$ (second ionization energy). This must correspond to a change in energy level. So, the atom of the element must have one valence electron and belong to group 1. In the case of Y, the largest jump in the ionization energy occurs between $IE_6$ (sixth ionization energy) and $IE_7$ (seventh ionization energy). So, the atom of the element must have six valence electrons and belong to group 16.
X forms cations with one positive charge whereas Y forms ions with two negative charges. As a result, the combination of $\ce{X+}$ and $\ce{Y^{2-}}$ is $\ce{X2Y}.$
This question is categorized as a medium as the student must use the information from successive ionization energies to deduce the corresponding group for the elements and then figure out how these are combined together.

title: Question 76
content:
Which of the following correctly describes the electron configuration of the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion?


- Number of occupied $p$ sublevelsNumber of occupied $p$ orbitalsA.$\hspace{1em}$26B.212C.62D.122
markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In the $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion, the electron configuration is $1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6.$ This means that two $p$ sublevels are occupied: $2p$ and $3p.$ Each of these sublevels includes three $p$ orbitals, and in this case, all six $p$ orbitals are fully occupied. Understanding the distinction between sublevels and orbitals is essential to interpreting electron configurations accurately.

title: Question 77
content: The successive ionization energies for element X are shown in the table below: $\textbf{Successive Ionization Energies (kJ mol}^{\mathbf{-1}})$1st IE2nd IE3rd IE4th IE5th IE6th IE7th IE8th IE1000225233634556700484962710831724 - Write the equation that represents the second ionization energy of element X. [1] - Predict the number of valence electrons for element X and justify your response. [2] - Another element, Y, is found below and in the same group as element X in the periodic table. The electronegativity value of element Y is 2.6. Predict a reasonable value for the electronegativity value of element X. Explain your reasoning.[2]
markScheme:
- $\ce{X^+(g) -> X^{2+}(g) + e^-}$ $\checkmark$
State symbols must be shown.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.
- element X has 6 valence electrons $\checkmark$
large jump between 6th and 7th IE $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
There is a large increase moving from the 6th IE to the 7th IE. This indicates that the 7th electron must be removed from a lower energy level closer to the nucleus as substantially more energy is required to remove the 7th electron.
- value between 2.6 and 3.4 $\checkmark$ 
smaller atom has higher electronegativity $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Element Y lies in the same group and below element X. Therefore, element Y has more energy levels in its atom than element X. Electronegativity is the attraction the atom of an element has for the shared pair of electrons in a covalent bond. This attraction will increase when there are fewer energy levels; hence electrons are closer to the nucleus or the atom, and the element has a higher electronegativity value.  The most electronegative atom in Group 16 is oxygen with 3.4.

title: Question 80
content:
Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?


- A. $\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7$
- B. $\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1$
- C. $\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).
Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy ($E \propto f$). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy is $n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)


This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

title: Question 2
content:
A mass spectrometer was used to determine that the relative ratio by mass of N : O in a molecule containing nitrogen and oxygen is $7 : 16.$ What is the most likely molecule?


- A.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO2}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\ce{NO3}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\ce{N2O5}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$
Mass ratio is $7:16$ or $14:32$ so it must be $\ce{NO2}.$
Alternatively, assume 7 g N and 16 g O, and convert to moles.  Use the molar ratio to deduce the empirical formula.

title: Question 4
content:
Which of the following statements is true?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula shows only the type of each atom in a molecule.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The molecular formula is always the same as the empirical formula.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Organic molecules often have different empirical and molecular formulas.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The empirical formula is always greater than the molecular formula.
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound. The empirical formula can sometimes be the same as the molecular formula. Choices A, B, and D are all false statements.

title: Question 6
content:
Calculate the number of moles in $20.5$ grams of sodium phosphate ($\ce{Na3PO4}$).


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 0.125 mol
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 1.25 mol
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 12.5 mol
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 125 mol
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The molar mass of sodium phosphate is 163.94 g mol$^{-1}$. Divide the mass (20.5 g) of sodium phosphate by the molar mass to calculate the number of moles of the compound. The rest of the choices are incorrect.

title: Question 9
content:
How many molecules are there in 4.80 mol of glucose?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3.50 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 2.59 $\times$ 10$^{24}$ molecules
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Use Avogadro's number to interconvert the number of molecules to the amount of molecules in moles:
$N = n \times N_{A}$ $N = 4.80\,\textrm{mol} \times \dfrac{6.02 \times 10^{23}\,\textrm{molecules}}{1\,\textrm{mol}}$ = 2.89 $\times$ 10$^{24}\,\text{molecules}$

title: Question 10
content: Eugenol is an oily, aromatic liquid extracted from essential oils such as clove and cinnamon. The molecular formula of eugenol is $\ce{C_{10}H_{12}O_{2}}.$ - Calculate the molar mass of eugenol. [1] - Determine the percentage by mass of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in eugenol. [3] - Predict the simplest, whole$-$number ratio of the atoms in eugenol. [1]
markScheme:
- Molar mass: M(C$_{10}$H$_{12}$O$_{2}$) $= 12.01 \times 10 + 1.01 \times 12 +16.00 \times 2 = 120.1 + 12.12 + 32.00 =\  $ $164.22 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
- Percentage by mass
  % C = $\left(\dfrac{120.1}{164.22}\right)$ (100)  = 73.13 % $\checkmark$
  % H = $\left(\dfrac{12.12}{164.22}\right)$ (100) = 7.38 % $\checkmark$
  % O = $\left(\dfrac{32.00}{164.22}\right)$ (100) = 19.49 % $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Divide the total mass of atoms of each element by the molar mass of eugenol and multiply it by 100
- The molecular formula of eugenol is C$_{10}$H$_{12}$O$_{2}$. Therefore, its empirical formula is C$_{5}$H$_{6}$O $\checkmark$  (ratio C : H : O = 5 : 6 : 1)

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$ 
Divide by the highest common factor (2) to determine the simplest whole number ratio

title: Question 12
content:
What is the percentage by mass of S in the compound sulfur dioxide $\ce{SO2}$?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 25%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 50%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 75%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 100%
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
% of S = $\left(\dfrac{32.07\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}{64.07\,\textrm{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\right)$ (100) = 50%
The percentage of sulfur in sulfur dioxide is 50%.

title: Question 22
content:
Which of the following solutions has the greatest quantity of moles of ions in solutions?


- A. $\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3$ of $1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
To determine the quantity of moles of ions in solution, each compound must be dissociated to reveal the stoichiometry. Next, the moles of each need to be considered using the equation $n = CV.$ The greatest quantity of ions will be found in the mixtures with the highest volume, so the $100\text{ cm}^3$ answer choices can be eliminated.
For NaCl:
$\ce{NaCl -> Na+ + Cl-}$ $n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{\ mol dm}^{-3})$ $n = 0.20\text{ mol NaCl}$
There is a $1:1$ relationship between the moles of compound and the moles of each ion, therefore there are a total of
$0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Na+} + 0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = 0.4\text{ mol of ions}$
For $\mathbf{\mathit{MgCl_2}}$:
$\ce{MgCl2 -> Mg^2+ + 2 Cl-}$ $n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3})$ $n = 0.20\text{ mol }\ce{MgCl2}$
There is a $1:1$ relationship between the moles of compound and $\ce{Mg^2+}$ and a $1:2$ relationship between the moles of compound and $\ce{Cl-},$ therefore there are a total of
$0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Mg^2+} + 0.4\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = \answer{0.6\text{ mol of ions}}$

title: Question 27
content: A student carried out an experiment to determine the empirical formula of an oxide of manganese. $3.60\,\text{g}$ of the metal was heated in the presence of an excess of oxygen. When the metal reacted completely, $5.64\,\text{g}$ of metal oxide were formed. - Deduce the empirical formula of the oxide. [3] - Suggest an experimental technique the student can use to ensure that the manganese has completely reacted. [1] - A common impurity in manganese is carbon. How would this impurity affect the determination of the empirical formula? [2]
markScheme:
- $m_\ce{O2} = 5.64 - 3.60 = 2.04\,\text{g}\ \checkmark$
  $n_\ce{Mn} = 0.0655$ AND $n_\ce{O2} = 0.128\ \checkmark$
  $\ce{MnO2}\ \checkmark$
  Award full marks for correct final answer.
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of oxygen can be obtained by subtracting the mass of the metal from the mass of the metal oxide.
  $m_\ce{Mn_xO_y} - m_\ce{Mn} = m_\ce{O}$ $5.62\,\text{g} - 3.60\,\text{g} = 2.02\,\text{g}$
  The moles for each of the elements can be obtained by applying the formula; $n = \dfrac{m}{M}$.
  $n_\ce{Mn} = \dfrac{3.60\,\text{g}}{54.94\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.0655\,\text{mol}$ $n_\ce{O} = \dfrac{2.04\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.128\,\text{mol}$
  The simplest ratio is obtained by dividing the moles of the substance by the smallest value of moles. This is the empirical formula:
  
  
  - Mn: $\dfrac{0.0655\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1$
  - O: $\dfrac{0.128\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1.95\approx 2$

  The empirical formula is $\ce{MnO2}$.
- Repeatedly heat and weigh until constant mass is achieved $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The mass of the sample is considered to have reached a constant value when the difference between successive weighings is minimal and falls within an acceptable range of experimental error. This indicates that all of the manganese has reacted with oxygen within practical restrictions.
- more oxygen will react per unit mass (to form $\ce{CO2})\,\checkmark$
  the ratio of O to Mn will be greater than 2 $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  If the manganese sample contains carbon as an impurity, it will also react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide. The additional mass of oxygen bonded to carbon would be incorrectly attributed to the formation of the manganese oxide. This would result in an overestimation of the oxygen content in the final product and an artificially high oxygen-to-manganes ratio. Consequently, the empirical formula of the manganese oxide would be determined incorrectly, potentially showing a higher number of oxygen atoms per manganese atom than is accurate (e.g., $\ce{MnO3}$ instead of $\ce{MnO2}).$

title: Question 3
content:
Based on the graph below, choose the correct statement that describes the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed mass and volume of a gas?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5b7d708-dada-487b-9f1b-ee2fb3f45b47/images/02187be4-3809-445d-b70e-4ae6dde3de0d/1.3-36.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the absolute temperature
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The graph of P vs T shows a linear graph (straight line passing through the origin) that rises upward. This graph shows that P is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. As the absolute temperature increases, the pressure of the gas also increases.

title: Question 5
content:
A sample of gas at the top of a mountain has a pressure of $75\text{ kPa}$ and a volume of $4.0\text{ dm}^3.$ If that same sample is brought to the bottom of the mountain where the pressure is now $100\text{ kPa},$ what is the new volume of the gas assuming that the temperature is kept constant?


- A. $\hspace{1em}0.75\text{ dm}^3$
- B. $\hspace{1em}0.19\text{ dm}^3$
- C. $\hspace{1em}3.0\text{ dm}^3$
- D. $\hspace{1em}5.3\text{ dm}^3$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This question is answered using the Ideal Gas Law equation, $PV = nRT.$ It is assumed that the moles of the gas are the same and the temperature remains constant, so we can set $PV$ for each scenario to be equal to each other:
$P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$
where

- $P_1V_1$ is  the pressure and volume at the top of the mountain
- $P_2V_2$ isthe pressure and volume at the bottom of the mountain

Rearranging,
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{P_2} = \dfrac{(75\text{ kPa})(4.0\text{ dm}^3)}{100\text{ kPa}} = \answer{3.0\text{ dm}^{3}}$

title: Question 10
content:
$14.01\,\text{g}$ of nitrogen gas ($\ce{N2}$) is reacted with excess $\ce{H2}$. What volume of ammonia ($\ce{NH3}$) gas would be produced at STP? The molar volume of a gas at STP is $22.7\,\text{dm}^3$.
$\ce{N2(g) + 3H2(g) -> 2NH3(g)}$


- A.$\hspace{1em} 11.4\,\text{dm}^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\,22.7\,\text{dm}^3$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\,34.1\,\text{dm}^3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\,45.4\,\text{dm}^3$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Calculate the number of moles of ammonia gas ($\ce{NH3}$) that will be produced from $14.01\,\text{g}$ of nitrogen gas $\ce{N2}$.
$n_\ce{N2} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{14.01\,\text{g}}{28.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.5\,\text{mol}$ $n_{\ce{NH3}} = 2\,n_{\ce{N2}} = 2 \times 0.5 = 1.0\,\text{mol}$
Calculate the volume of ammonia gas produced at STP.
$V = n  V_m = 1.0\,\text{mol} \times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = \answer{22.7\,\text{dm}^3}$
$\ $

title: Question 13
content:
Which of the following gases most closely aligns with the behavior of an ideal gas?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}$, bromine
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{H2}$, hydrogen
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cl2}$, chlorine
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{O2}$, oxygen
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The student must understand the concepts behind an ideal gas which assumes negligent volume and insignificant attractive forces between atoms or molecules.
As the molar mass of a chemical species increases, the attractive forces between particles also increase. This causes a deviation from the ideal gas model as the relative molecular mass increases.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must apply logic to the definition of an ideal gas.

title: Question 14
content:
Which statement(s) is (are) correct about real gases?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Gas particles are considered to have negligible volume.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$At low temperatures, intermolecular forces exist.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$At high pressure, real gases behave as ideal gases.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Ideal gases are described as moving particles with no volume and no intermolecular forces. In contrast, real gases take into account the small volume of particles and the intermolecular forces that can cause a deviation from the ideal behavior.
Statement I is incorrect as it applies to ideal gases only.
Real gases behave like ideal gases at high temperatures and low pressures. Statement III is incorrect.
At low temperatures, condensed phases exist, and intermolecular forces are significant. Statement II is correct.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must thoroughly compare and distinguish ideal and real gases.

title: Question 16
content:
A sample of gas at a certain temperature, pressure, and volume ($T_1$, $P_1$, and $V_1$) undergoes a change in temperature and pressure ($T_2$ and $P_2$). What is the new volume ($V_2$)?


- 
  
  - Before: $T_1, P_1, V_1$
  - After:	$P_2 = 2P_1 \quad \textrm{AND} \quad T_2 = \frac{1}{2} T_1$




- A.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{2} V_1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{8} V_1$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{4} V_1$
- D.$\hspace{1em}4V_1$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Use the combined gas law:
$\dfrac{P_1 V_1}{T_1}= \dfrac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}$ $V_2 =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 T_2}{T_1 P_2} =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 \ \frac{1}{2}T_1}{T_1\ 2P_1} =\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}V_1}{2} =$ $\frac{1}{4} V_1$
Alternate Method:
To answer this question, the student must understand and apply the relationships between temperature, pressure, and volume in the ideal gas model:
$PV = nRT$
Therefore, $V \propto T$ and $P \propto \dfrac{1}{V}$.
Since volume and temperature are directly proportional, an increase in one will result in an increase in the other at the same magnitude.
In this case, $T_2 = \frac{1}{2}  T_1$ resulting in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Pressure is doubled, but since volume and pressure are inversely proportional, this results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Compounding these effects results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{4} V_1$.
This question is categorized as medium because it requires an understanding of the ideal gas law and proportionalities based on $PV = nRT$.

title: Question 17
content:
Which graph depicts the behavior of a fixed amount of an ideal gas at constant temperature?


- A.$\hspace{0em}$B.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/9586b562-a724-4700-8648-f80b6cc09ee9/CH1226a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/85d6b7c7-0a9a-438d-91b4-42e6561c0767/CH1226b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/2c47e38d-63db-449a-9d59-ae78aa73e245/CH12261c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/ef61e732-30a3-4a19-938e-e398139c55e0/CH1226d.png)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
At constant temperature, an ideal gas obeys Boyle's law, so the product  $PV = \textrm{constant}.$ When $V$ is plotted against
$P,$ the curve must therefore be a  hyperbola because volume decreases inversely as pressure increases. If instead $\frac{1}{V}$ is plotted against $P,$ the two quantities are directly proportional and produce a straight line through the origin. Finally, a plot of $PV$ vs. $P$ should be a horizontal line, since
$PV$ does not change with pressure for an ideal gas at fixed temperature.
For ideal gases:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/c4710df2-772b-4aba-993e-dc6c21b2d238/CH1226hyperbola.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/0583432a-e106-4649-84a9-1df1388166c9/Screenshot%202025-09-23%20at%202.20.38%E2%80%AFPM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/93ce3c7f-1dfb-48a0-96ed-91708dd0f328/CH1226PVvsPideal.png)


This question is categorized as hard as students must predict the shape of the curve for the relationship between pressure and volume in an ideal gas at a constant temperature.
